required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pre-hospital Post ROSC Care: Are we Achieving Our Targets?
clinical_study.official_title: Which Patients With a ROSC After OHCA Would Potentially Benefit From Physician Driven Post Cardiac Arrest Care?

brief_summary.textblock:
Rational: Out of hospital cardiac arrest is a devastating event with a high mortality. Survival rates have increased over the last years, with the availability of AED's and public BLS. Previous studies have shown that deranged physiology after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) is associated with a worse neurological outcome. Good quality post-arrest care is therefore of utmost importance.
Objective: To determine how often prehospital crews (with their given skills set) encounter problems meeting optimal post-ROSC targets in patients suffering from OHCA, and to investigate if this can be predicted based on patient-, provider- or treatment factors.
Study design: Prospective cohort study of all patients attended by the EMS services with an OHCA who regain ROSC and are transported to a single university hospital, in order to identify those patients with a ROSC after a non-traumatic OHCA who had deranged physiology and/or complications from OHCA EMS personnel was unable to prevent/deal with in the prehospital environment.
Study population: Patients, >18 years, transported by the EMS services to the ED of the University Hospital Groningen (UMCG) with a ROSC after OHCA in a 1 year period
Main study parameters/endpoints: Primary endpoint of our study is the percentage of OHCA patients with a prehospital ROSC who arrive in hospital with either a deranged physiology or with complications from OHCA EMS personnel was unable to deal with.

primary_outcome.measure: percentage of OHCA patients with a prehospital ROSC who arrive in hospital with either a deranged physiology or with complications from OHCA EMS personnel was unable to deal with
primary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1-2 hours
primary_outcome.description: Any of the below 5 minutes or more after ROSC is obtained: -Airway intervention (SGA or ETT) not performed (when deemed necessary) Actively Vomiting in absence of ETT after ROSC B: -Hypoxia: -SaO2 <94% on at least two consecutive readings Hypercarbia: -ETCO2>5.5 kPa on at least two consecutive readings** C: -Low cardiac output: -Re-arrest during transport to hospital ETCO2<3.0 on two consecutive readings MAP<65mmHg on two consecutive readings SBP<100 mmHg on two consecutive readings upon arrival in ED D: -Hypoxic agitation upon arrival in ED or uncontrolled prehospital hypoxic agitation despite benzodiazepine administration or when benzodiazepines contraindicated) Seizures during transport E: -Hyperthermia

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of period with deranged physiology, measured from moment of first occurrence until resolved or until arrival in hospital.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1-2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Any of the following measured in minutes: -Airway intervention (SGA or ETT) not performed (when deemed necessary) Actively Vomiting in absence of ETT after ROSC B: -Hypoxia: -SaO2 <94% on at least two consecutive readings Hypercarbia: -ETCO2>5.5 kPa on at least two consecutive readings** C: -Low cardiac output: -Re-arrest during transport to hospital ETCO2<3.0 on two consecutive readings MAP<65mmHg on two consecutive readings SBP<100 mmHg on two consecutive readings upon arrival in ED D: -Hypoxic agitation upon arrival in ED or uncontrolled prehospital hypoxic agitation despite benzodiazepine administration or when benzodiazepines contraindicated) Seizures during transport E: -Hyperthermia

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient- and resuscitation factors related to deranged physiology and/or complications in the post arrest phase
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1-2 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Opinion of EMS providers weather or not they felt they were able to provide optimal post arrest care
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at emergency department, approximately 1-2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by a survey, filled out by EMS crew at arrival at ED

secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of primary outcome of secondary outcomes between post ROSC patients attended by EMS only vs EMS and HEMS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at emergency department, approximately 1-2 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency distribution of airway interventions (SGA or ETT) not performed (when deemed necessary)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at emergency department, approximately 1-2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: -Airway intervention (SGA or ETT) not performed (when deemed necessary) in ED. NB NOT change of SGA for ETT when SGA is functioning well

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency distribution of actively vomiting in absence of ETT after ROSC in prehospital setting
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1 to 2 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency distribution of the presence of hypoxia
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1 to 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: SaO2 <94% on at least two consecutive readings

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency distribution of low cardiac output
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to ICU (or CCU) admission, up to about 1 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Presence of one of the following: Re-arrest during transport to hospital ETCO2<3.0 on two consecutive readings MAP<65mmHg on two consecutive readings 12 SBP<100 mmHg on two consecutive readings

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency distribution of hypoxic agitation upon arrival in ED or uncontrolled prehospital hypoxic agitation despite benzodiazepine administration or when benzodiazepines contraindicated)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1-2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed by physician who enrolls patient

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency distribution of seizures during transport
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1-2 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency distribution of the presence of hyperthermia
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From pre-hospital ROSC to arrival at ED, approximately 1-2 hours

study_pop.textblock: Adult (>18 years) patients with ROSC after OHCA transported to University Hospital Groningen by the EMS services.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- Non-traumatic OHCA (as confirmed in notes of ambulance crew) with ROSC obtained before transport to hospital
- Age > 18
Exclusion criteria:
- Traumatic cause of arrest (NB asphyxia due to hanging, electrocutions and drowning are not considered as traumatic arrests in this study, as normal ALS algorithms (special circumstances) are followed for these patients
- No ROSC before leaving OHCA
- Age <18
- Informed opt out of medical research of patient
